abstract.p: This paper presents a hybrid control method for active vibration control of smart piezoelectric structures. The proposed controller consists of a proportional derivative (PD) controller for broadband disturbance rejection and a repetitive controller for narrowband disturbance rejection. The proposed design embeds the repetitive controller by solving a Bezout identity satisfying deterministic constraint into an existing PD feedback control loop. The applied method has two main advantages: (1) each controller design is modularized with an “add-on” property for performance improvement; (2) it achieves superior vibration suppression for both impulse and persistent excitation. Experimental results on a piezoelectric cantilever beam demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid controller design method.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Flexible structures have recently generated a lot of interest in the aerospace and civil engineering communities due to their relatively light weight and compact design flexibility in large structures. To cope with low damping and undesired vibrations caused by external disturbances, smart materials such as piezoelectric zirconate titanate (PZT) ceramics and piezoelectric polymer poly vinylidene fluoride (PVDF) can actively minimize the vibration response. This is an effective technology that has become increasingly important for industries. As a result, researchers have developed many control strategies and sensors and actuators made from various smart materials to achieve the active vibration control of smart flexible structures in the past few decades.

Existing controllers generally fall into two groups based on the fact that two kinds of signals always exist as disturbance sources: broadband and narrowband signals. Narrowband signals usually contain monotonic components and will excite the vibration of structures at or near their resonant frequencies. Methods aimed at suppressing the vibration at specific resonant modes are called narrow band methods. For example, a positive position feedback (PPF) (Fanson and Caughey, 1990) controller and its variation (Moheimani et al., 2006) is a second-order low-pass filter in the feedback control loop with a tuning gain. Input shaping (Shan et al., 2005; Singh and Singhose, 2002) is a feed-forward control technique that generates an input sequence by convolving a desired command with a series of impulses. This method is widely used to suppress the vibration of smart structures because of its simplicity and easy implementation in computer-controlled systems.

However, a common drawback to using narrowband methods is limited performance in rejecting unexpected or complex disturbances. Feed-forward control techniques such as input shaping (Shan et al., 2005) are very sensitive to modeling errors, and require accurate models for guaranteed performance. Although PPF controllers are insensitive to un-modeled high frequency dynamics (spillover), the small tuning gain range in this type of controller limits suppression performance, and particularly when dealing with disturbances other than resonant frequency signals. For this reason, broadband methods, in the sense that the controller design considers a broader frequency range of disturbances and a larger control bandwidth, belong to another group that is opposite to narrowband methods. Besides suppressing at resonant frequencies, broadband methods achieve a certain level of vibration attenuation without knowing the external disturbance dynamics a priori. Several popular broadband methods include proportional derivative (PD) (Shen and Homaifar, 2001) control and state space optimal control strategies, such as linear quadratic (LQ) (Shen and Homaifar, 2001; Yagiz and Hacioglu, 2005) and H∞ control (Moheimani et al., 1999; Chen et al., 2007; Lorga et al., 2009). However, one issue these broadband methods may encounter and should carefully address is the performance constraint arising from the classical Bode integral constraint on sensitivity (Balas and Doyle, 1994; Skogestad and Postlethwaite, 1996). While minimizing the sensitivity function at resonant modes can obtain the desired performance, it also unintentionally increases the magnitude of sensitivity at undesired frequency regions and deteriorates the suppression performance subjected to these frequency signals.

In light of the reasons described above, it is natural that researchers should start using hybrid control methods that include narrowband and broadband methods to achieve better active vibration control (Orszulik and Shan, 2010; Mohamed et al., 2005; Shan et al., 2005; Qiu et al., 2007; Hu, 2008). Shan et al. (2005) presented a hybrid controller that combines modified input shaping with PD control law to achieve vibration suppression in a rotating single-link flexible manipulator. In this case, the stability is not affected by adding a feed-forward controller to an existing feedback control loop. This type of hybrid idea is straightforward and attractive to researchers (Orszulik and Shan, 2010; Mohamed et al., 2005; Hu, 2008). Because most hybrid methods integrate two or more feedback controllers, it is important to ensure stability because enhancing the performance in the feedback loop at the same time may decrease robustness or stability. As an example, Qiu et al. (2007) reported a hybrid PPF/PD control method that can increase the tuning gain range in the PPF controller, improving performance without sacrificing stability.

This paper investigates the effectiveness of a hybrid control method combining PD and repetitive control for active vibration control of smart flexible structures. As a narrowband method, repetitive control (Tomizuka et al., 1989; Prell et al., 1999) is an advanced feedback control technique that includes an internal model of input signals and can effectively track or reject periodic signals. This hybrid control structure allows the sensitivity function of all controllers to be multiplied together, enhancing disturbance rejection performance targeted at interested frequency ranges. The goal of this hybrid controller design is to take advantage of both methods and use repetitive control and PD control to reject narrowband and broadband disturbances more effectively.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 reviews the modeling and modal analysis of a cantilevered beam for the study. Section 3 presents the design of the hybrid controller accompanied with performance and robust stability analysis. Sections 4 and 5 illustrate the experimental setup and experimental results with discussion, respectively. Finally, Section 6 concludes the study.

sec.title: 2. Modeling and modal analysis
sec.p: To analyze the beam dynamics and obtain useful information for controller design, this section derives a mathematical model and resonant modes of a piezoelectric cantilever beam using Bernoulli-Euler beam theory (Moheimani and Fleming, 2006).

sec.title: 2.1. Modeling and resonance for a cantilever beam
sec.p: Using Newton’s force equilibrium and Euler beam’s bending moment (equation (1)), it is possible to obtain the equation of motion (2) when applying transverse force to the beam. Equation (2) is a multi-variable partial differential equation (PDE reviewed in Preumont (2002). (1)∂2w(x,t)∂x2=M(x,t)EI (2)∂4w(x,t)∂x4+ρA(x)EI∂2w(x,t)∂t2=F(x,t) where I, E, ρ, and A represent the moment of inertia, Young’s modulus, mass density, and cross-sectional area of the beam, respectively. To derive the modal function, first assume that the beam is in free vibration response, i.e., F(x,t) = 0 in equation (2). Next, use the method of separation of variables for w(x,t): (3)w(x,t)=ϕ(x)q(t) where ϕ(x) is a modal shape function with spatial variable x and q(t) is the beam’s transverse function with time variable t. Given a one fixed end cantilever beam for 0 ≦ x ≦L, the boundary condition satisfies the following constraints: (4)ϕ(0)=0,ϕ'(0)=0,ϕ″(L)=0,ϕ″'(L)=0
Substituting equations (3) and (4) into equation (2) and skipping the details, the beam’s characteristic equation is as follows: (5)cos(βnL)cosh(βnL)+1=0

The characteristic values βnL corresponding to the nth resonant frequency can be solved using standard numerical methods. Some examples are given as follows (Ballas, 2007): (6)β1L=1.875104,β2L=4.694091, β3L=7.854757…
The beam’s natural frequency, which satisfies the assumption (2), has the representation as: (7)ωn=(βnL)2EIρA(x)L4(rad/sec) n=1,2,…
Superposing all the modes together, the free vibration response and position function w(x,t) of a cantilever beam is (8)w(x,t)=∑i=1∞ϕi(x)qi(t)
For each mode, ϕi(x) and qi(t) represent the normalized mode shape function and transverse function, respectively.

sec.title: 2.2. Dynamics of a piezoelectric driven beam
sec.p:
This study applies piezoelectric patches to generate a forcing moment and deflect the beam for vibration control evaluation. Figures 1 and 2 show that this approach combines a PVDF sensor with a collocated actuator-sensor pair to measure the feedback and control beam’s dynamic response related to the piezoelectric patch specs such as length Lpx, width Lpy, and attached actuator location x1 and sensor location x2. The beam’s dimensions, including height h, width W, and length L, determine the magnitude of produced bending moment Ma, which particularly affects its dynamic response. Assume that hp and the sensor height hc are much smaller than h for uniform beam properties. As a result, EI and ρA are uniform over the length of the beam. Because the patches are tightly glued to the beam with minimal shear stress, it is possible to simply consider the beam’s transverse motion in the Z-axis and neglect longitudinal deflection. Figure 1.
Top view of a beam combining piezoelectric patches.
Figure 2.
A flexible beam driven by piezoelectric patches.

Applying an external voltage Va(t) drives the piezoelectric patch actuator and generates an equivalent bending moment Ma as the forcing function by piezoelectricity effect (Moheimani and Fleming, 2006) (Figure 2). The moment deflecting the beam can be represented as (9)Ma=K¯Va(t)K¯=EIkd31hpk=12Eahp(h+hp)2Eh3+Ea[(h+2hp)3-h3] where K¯ is a constant based on the properties of the beam and piezoelectric patches as defined in Moheimani and Fleming (2006), d31 and Ea represent the strain constant and Young’s modulus of piezoelectric patches, respectively. Substituting equation (9) into equation (2) and using the orthogonality properties and Dirac’s function property (Moheimani and Fleming, 2006) produces the following set of uncoupled ordinary differential equations: (10)q··i(t)+2ξiωiq·i(t)+ωi2qi(t)=K¯ρAΨiVa(t) where i = 1,2,3, … , and Ψi is a function of the location of the piezoelectric actuator-sensor pair. The term qi(t) indicates the generalized coordinate for the ith mode. The dynamic equation (10), which combines the piezoelectric patches, is the model mostly applied for the controller design. The model includes a damping term 2ξiωi for each mode i because this is true in actual beam vibration. To be more precise, Ψi can be written as follows: (11)Ψi=[ϕ'i(x2)-ϕ'i(x1)] where x1 and x2 represent the locations of the end of the piezoelectric actuator and sensor pair along the X-axis.

sec.title: 3. Hybrid controller design
sec.p:
Figure 3 illustrates the block diagram of the hybrid controller for active vibration control of flexible structures. The control goal here is to suppress the vibration effect caused by external disturbances d, or equivalently to regulate the system output y. The applied hybrid controller comprises a PD controller C1 and a repetitive controller C2 as Figure 3(b) shows. The key idea of this hybrid controller is to introduce a control structure that transforms the original feedback control problem into a feed-forward control problem for repetitive controller design. This control structure has a positive feedback loop and includes an estimated plant model Ĝ, motivated by the “inverse control” concept introduced in Widrow and Walach (1996). Based on this technique, the proposed design includes a repetitive controller for narrowband disturbance rejection, while another feedback controller, PD controller, ensures broadband disturbance rejection. The design details of these two controllers are presented as follows.
PD controller
Figure 3.
Block diagram of the closed loop system using hybrid controller.

The PD control law has the following representation: (12)u1=Kpv(k)+Kdv(k)-v(k-1) where Kp and Kd represent the proportional gain and derivative gain, respectively.
Repetitive controller

A repetitive controller is a feedback controller that includes an internal model of input signals. This type of controller can eliminate periodic disturbances based on the internal model principle (Francis and Wonham, 1976). Researchers have developed various repetitive controllers for many control applications, including prototype repetitive control (Tomizuka et al., 1989), robust repetitive control (Li and Tsao, 2001), and the internal model control approach mentioned in Lin and Tsao (2007). The applied repetitive controller in this study is similar to the technique presented in Lin and Tsao (2007), but excludes an adaptive controller component. First, disable the PD controller in the control block diagram in Figure 3(b). In practice, the sensor measurement v involves sensor amplifier dynamics and is only useful in some frequency range determined by the cutoff frequency of the low pass filter in the amplifier. However, to simplify the analysis, this study assumes that v ∼ = y for convenience. The transfer function from exogenous input d to system output y can be derived as follows: (13)y=1-G∧C21-G∧C2+GC2d where Ĝ is the plant model of G and can be obtained using a finite element model (Preumont, 2002) or system identification methods (Ljung and Ljung, 1987). Assuming that the system plant is stable and the identified plant model is sufficiently accurate, meaning that Ĝ ≈ G, equation (13) then becomes (14)y=(1-G∧C2)d

The original feedback control problem has been transformed to a feed-forward control problem. Thus, the control goal here is to minimize the tracking error with a cost function J = (1 − ĜC2). The simplest solution to this control problem is to find a stable plant inverse of Ĝ (Tomizuka, 1987). Several performance indexes, such as 2-norm or infinity-norm, can be used for different optimal control problems (Tsao, 1994). For practical applications, consider the case when the system input contains some specific internal models D, which is usually known a priori. To control the vibration of flexible structures, an important goal is to minimize the significant structural responses under persistent excitation at or near resonant frequencies. Therefore, it is natural to choose a periodic signal generator D = 1 – z−N, whose period N corresponds to the fundamental frequency and resonant modes in the repetitive controller design. Let (15)1-G∧C2=RDorG∧C2+RD=1 where R is a part of the controller C2 and needs to be designed later. The equation above can be recognized as the famous “Bezout Identity” (Skogestad and Postlethwaite, 1996) with the assumption that Ĝ and D are coprime.

Next, consider a single input, single output (SISO) plant model Ĝ and factorize Ĝ into two parts, Ĝ = GoGi in which Go is the minimum phase and Gi is the non-minimum phase, respectively. Suppose (16)G∧=BA=B+B-A=GoGiGo=B+A,Gi=B- where A and B represent the denominator and numerator of Ĝ, and B+ and B- indicate the stable and unstable parts of B, respectively. Substituting equation (16) into equation (15), one can obtain (17)RD+C~Gi=1C~=C2Go

From the plant inversion idea presented in Tomizuka (1987) one solution pair (R',C') to solve (17) is given as follows: (18)R'=11-(1-γGi*Gi)qz-NC~=γGi*qz-N1-(1-γGi*Gi)qz-NC'=C~Go-1 where γ is a learning gain for performance tuning, Gi*(z-1)=Gi(z), and q is a zero phase low-pass filter to suppress the instability caused by the high gain feedback at undesired frequency ranges. Note that this q filter is embedded within the selected internal model as D=1-q(z,z-1)z-N. Refer to Lin and Tsao (2007) and Pérez-Arancibia et al. (2010) for a detailed analysis of the design parameters and nominal stability condition in equation (18).
Controller performance and robust stability

One way to evaluate the control performance of a linear time invariant (LTI) control system is to check its sensitivity function, i.e., transfer function from disturbance input d to system output y. Equation (19) shows that the overall sensitivity function of the hybrid controller S comprises two control efforts coming from PD controller C1 and repetitive controller C2, where SC1 and S∧C2 represent the corresponding sensitivity function, respectively. These two synergetic sensitivity functions can achieve enhanced vibration suppression performance as long as C1 and C2 are appropriately designed. (19)S=SC1S∧C2SC1=11+GC1=11+G[(Kp+Kd)-Kdz-1]S∧C2=1-G∧C2=1-qz-N1-(1-γGi*Gi)qz-N

This compact representation C2 requires that Ĝ ≈ G. The “hat” notation in S∧C2 is due to this reason and S∧C2 can be referred to as “estimated sensitivity” for clarity. However, it is impractical to use a plant model Ĝ to satisfy this perfect plant assumption and the above hybrid control structure is very sensitive to plant parameters and unmodeled dynamics. The following theorem derives a useful verifying condition to ensure robust stability for this hybrid control system:

Theorem 1: Consider an LTI hybrid control system with multiplicative input uncertainty Δ and a stable weight WI for the uncertainty in Figure 4. Here, Ĝ is the nominal plant. Assuming that Δ is a set of stable transfer functions such that |Δ(jω)| < 1 for all ω and the system is nominally stable for Ĝ, the hybrid control system is robustly stable if and only if (20)|WI|<|1+G∧C1(C1+C2)G∧|,∀ω Figure 4.
Hybrid control system with multiplicative input uncertainty.

Proof: It is straightforward to transform the original block diagram to the equivalent feedback system as Figure 5 shows, where (21)T=(C1+C2)G∧1+G∧C1 Figure 5.
Equivalent feedback system for robust stability analysis.
Because by assumption WI and T are stable, the small gain theorem can immediately obtain the following condition |W1T| < 1 ∀ω, which completes the proof.

sec.title: 4. Experimental setup
sec.p:
This study used an aluminum flexible beam for active vibration control experiments. Table 1 lists the beam properties. A piezoelectric patch actuator (Model No. SB4020008 from Piezo actuator™) and a PVDF sensor (Model No. LDT0-028 K/L from MEAS) were surface bonded to the fixed end of the cantilever beam as a pair of collocated piezoelectric actuator-sensor patches. Table 2 summarizes the properties of the piezoelectric patches. Figures 6 and 7 present the real-time vibration control experiment schematic diagram and hardware apparatus, respectively. A third PZT patch used to excite the resonant mode was attached to the free end of the beam. A 20-times voltage amplifier (VP7206 made by PiezoMaster) was used to supply enough voltage input to actuate the PZT actuator and suppress the structural vibration. A sensor amplifier (Piezo film lab amplifier made by MEAS) with a 30 mV rms noise level and an 0.1 Hz ∼ 10 Hz band-pass filter setup was adopted to filter out unwanted noises and obtain useful measurement for feedback control. This is because this study is primarily concerned with the suppression of a beam’s first mode, whose resonant frequency is approximately 6 Hz, following the modal analysis presented in Section 2.1. Hybrid control algorithms were implemented using MATLAB Simulink, and the data was acquired by a 16-bit A/D and 12-bit D/A DAQ board (PCIM-DAS1602/16) at a 3 kHz sampling rate. Figure 6.

This experiment used two experimental setups to provide impulse and persistent excitation. An extra PZT actuator was applied as an exciter to generate persistent excitation near the beam’s resonant frequency (Figure 6). For the impulse excitation experiment, this study designed and built an apparatus transforming potential energy to mechanical energy (Figure 8). A steel ball was electromagnetically attached to a coil winding bar at a certain height as the initial position. The ball was dropped by disabling the electric current and magnetic force at the computer side. After dropping, the ball passed through an aluminum inclined track and struck the end of the beam, resulting in an impulse excitation. There are several advantages to using this apparatus to generate impulse excitation. First, the dropping time of the ball or the hitting time is synchronized with a fixed contact point, keeping the impulse force consistent for every experiment. Moreover, the amplitude of the impulse excitation can be systematically determined by adjusting the initial height of the ball or the tilting angle of the track. Figure 8.
Photograph of the apparatus for impulse excitation experiment.

sec.title: 5. Experimental results and discussion
sec.p: This section first presents system identification results to facilitate the proposed controller design. This section then presents vibration control experimental results on a flexible cantilever beam and provides discussion based on frequency and time domain analysis.

sec.title: 5.1. System identification
sec.p:
The detailed model derived in Section 2 is useful for modal analysis, and particularly for system setup. However, the derived model is quite complicated and the resulting controller order may be too high to be implemented with satisfactory performance. This study aims to suppress the first mode of the beam and thus only necessitates a second order mathematical model for controller design. To obtain a simplified control oriented model for model based controller design presented in this study, a system identification technique was performed by injecting a time series of random binary signal and recording the sensor output as input and output data. The random frequency range was from 0 ∼ 15 Hz sampled at 3 kHz for 10 secs. Using the system identification toolbox in Matlab and filtering out high frequency dynamics enables a discretized second order model to be fitted. Figure 9 presents the identification results. Figure 9.
Measured and simulated model output.

sec.title: 5.2. Hybrid controller synthesis
sec.p:
This section presents the controller parameter analysis using the sensitivity plot, and aims to provide a guideline for designing high performance hybrid controllers. Figure 10 shows the sensitivity plot SC1 and illustrates the disturbance rejection ability of the PD controller by comparing it with three sets of PD parameters. As mentioned in Section 1, the so-called “Bode integral constraint” appears in broadband design methods such as PD control. It is clear that applying larger Kp reduces the sensitivity magnitude in the low frequency range and achieves better vibration suppression performance. However, the magnitude also increases, and particularly at a relatively higher frequency range. For example, the PD controller with Kp = 2.6 exhibits fair attenuation (magnitude in dB is less than zero) only for input signals with frequency components less than 9 Hz. Beyond this frequency, the PD controller increases the sensitivity magnitude and amplifies the system output, and particularly at around 12 Hz, deteriorating the control performance significantly. Therefore, designers should carefully select control parameters and avoid unintentional excitation in the danger zone if possible. Figure 10.
Sensitivity plot SC1: proportional derivative controller.

Figure 11 shows the estimated sensitivity plot S∧C2 with three design cases by adjusting the learning gain γ. A low pass q filter was selected as a zero phase filter with a cut-off frequency of approximately 40 Hz. As a narrowband design method, the repetitive controller in this study generates deep notches at multiple frequencies of 6 Hz. This is why a repetitive controller can effectively suppress persistent excitation disturbance near its resonant frequency. Increasing γ can produce a deeper notch but increases the magnitude at frequencies higher than 25 Hz, similar to the result in PD control case. Figure 11.
Sensitivity plot S∧C2: Repetitive controller.

Based on the results above, it is possible to select appropriate design parameters for a specific frequency range to achieve better disturbance rejection (Figure 12). It is obvious that the resulting sensitivity plot preserves the advantages of each controller and demonstrates the effectiveness of synergetic ideas followed by the experimental results in the next section. Figure 12.
Sensitivity plot SC1/S∧C2: Hybrid controller.

sec.title: 5.3. Vibration control results and discussion
sec.p: This experiment used two sets of different disturbance sources including an impulse and persistent resonant input as excitation signals for active vibration control evaluation. For each case, PD controller, repetitive controller, and hybrid PD/repetitive controller were applied for performance comparison.

sec.title: 5.3.1. Vibration suppression under impulse excitation
sec.p:
As described in the previous section, this study uses the designed apparatus and generates free vibration by throwing a steel ball at the free end of the beam. Figure 13 illustrates the frequency responses of the uncontrolled and controlled output using fast Fourier transform (FFT). Figures 14 to 16 show the time responses of the three control methods. Applying PD control achieved obvious vibration suppression at a resonant frequency of approximately 5.5 Hz. The actual resonant frequency obtained from experimental data was slightly less than the value (about 5.8 Hz) coming from the modal analysis, because of the extra mass of the attached actuators and sensors. The results in Figure 15 indicate that applying repetitive control (RC) exhibits no suppression effect compared to the no control case. This is not surprising because RC is designed on the basis of the fundamental frequency (6 Hz in this experiment) of the applied internal model corresponding to the characteristics of external disturbances. As a narrowband design method, RC is incapable of rejecting broadband disturbances such as impulse excitation. Figure 13.
Frequency responses of the controlled output by fast Fourier transform under impulse excitation.
Figure 14.
Time response of the controlled output under impulse excitation: proportional derivative control method.
Figure 15.
Time response of the controlled output under impulse excitation: repetitive control method.
Figure 16.
Time responses of the controlled output under impulse excitation: comparison of proportional derivative and hybrid proportional derivative/repetitive control method.

To remedy this drawback and further improve the performance in rejecting both broadband and narrowband disturbances, this study proposes an “add-on” concept that combines the PD and repetitive controller together with the aid of the control structure presented in Section 3. Figure 16 clearly shows that applying hybrid PD/RC control shows better vibration attenuation with smaller transient output amplitude than using PD control alone.

sec.title: 5.3.2. Vibration suppression under resonant excitation
sec.p:
The results above demonstrate that the proposed hybrid controller can achieve vibration suppression under impulse excitation. To further illuminate the practical use of a repetitive controller as part of the hybrid controller, this study excites the beam’s first mode by injecting a 6 Hz sinusoidal input near the resonant frequency at 5.5 Hz. Figure 17 shows the vibration control results by comparing the frequency responses of the sensor output after employing an FFT algorithm. As expected, there is a significant resonant peak without any control. Applying PD and RC control reduced the peak amplitude by about 50% and 75%, respectively. The proposed hybrid controller shows up to more than 88% attenuation compared with the no control case. Although including feedback control increases the peak and may deteriorate the performance at DC (very low) frequencies (as shown in the plot), it is not a major concern here because the goal of this experiment is to suppress the vibration coming from persistent resonant excitation. Figure 17.
Frequency responses of the controlled output by fast Fourier transform under resonant excitation.

Besides frequency domain results and analysis, this section also presents the time domain results (Figures 18 to 20) for illustration and comparison purposes. Figure 17 shows that the controlled output remains at about 50% magnitude, which is the same as the frequency domain analysis. The result is further improved by applying the RC control method in Figure 19. Because of the included internal model, the repetitive controller improves the control input iteratively and reduces the vibration output after a couple of cycles, reaching the steady state in less than 10 secs. The ripples after transience mainly come from the use of low pass q filter in the repetitive controller, to avoid unmodeled high frequency dynamics excitation and instability. Figure 18.
Time response of the controlled output under resonant excitation: proportional derivative control method.
Figure 19.
Time response of the controlled output under resonant excitation: repetitive control method.
Figure 20.
Time responses of the controlled output under resonant excitation: comparison of repetitive and hybrid proportional derivative/repetitive control method.

Finally, Figure 20 illustrates the concept of combining PD and RC control as one hybrid controller. The hybrid PD/RC controller not only improves the transient performance, but also removes the unwanted ripples occurring at steady state, regulating the controlled output to almost sensor noise level.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: This study presents a hybrid control technique that combines PD control with repetitive control to achieve the active vibration control of smart piezoelectric flexible structures. Vibration control experiments were conducted on an aluminum cantilever beam by exciting the beam with impulse and resonant frequency inputs. The results of this study can be summarized as follows: 1. Repetitive control is particularly effective for narrowband disturbance rejection such as persistent resonant excitation, but has its limitations in rejecting broadband disturbances such as impulse excitation; 2. To demonstrate the practicality of repetitive control in suppressing more complicated disturbances, the applied hybrid PD/repetitive control method shows more apparent performance improvement than using either traditional PD control or repetitive control alone. These results verify the effectiveness of the proposed combination of these two control methods.
